To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

slidelink.displaytext: Scenarios | Engaging students in Purposeful Practice

search.slidetext: scenarios engaging students in purposeful practice the following scenarios demonstrate three different approaches to supportinga class of students who are increasingly disengaged during purposeful practice. to access the scenario select the begin button below, then use the arrowbuttons on the bottom of the slide to navigate the scenario. begin begin begin begin begin begin select the scenario to begin.

provide incentives for her students to spend more time and effort on tasks to improve the quality of their work. remove purposeful practice from the teaching sequence and add additional modelled and guided practice to ensure her students' engagement. adopt more varied, purposeful practice tasks. scenarios: engaging students in purposeful practice provide incentives for her students to spend more time and effort on tasks to improve the quality of their work. provide incentives for her students to spend more time and effort on tasks to improve the quality of their work. provide incentives for her students to spend more time and effort on tasks to improve the quality of their work. provide incentives for her students to spend more time and effort on tasks to improve the quality of their work. provide incentives for her students to spend more time and effort on tasks to improve the quality of their work. provide incentives for her students to spend more time and effort on tasks to improve the quality of their work. remove purposeful practice from the teaching sequence and add additional modelled and guided practice to ensure her students' engagement. remove purposeful practice from the teaching sequence and add additional modelled and guided practice to ensure her students' engagement. remove purposeful practice from the teaching sequence and add additional modelled and guided practice to ensure her students' engagement. remove purposeful practice from the teaching sequence and add additional modelled and guided practice to ensure her students' engagement. remove purposeful practice from the teaching sequence and add additional modelled and guided practice to ensure her students' engagement. remove purposeful practice from the teaching sequence and add additional modelled and guided practice to ensure her students' engagement. scenario ms. n, a year 2 teacher, regularly used the same purposeful practice activities and strategies. recently, she noticed that during the purposeful practice phase of the explicit teaching sequence, many students were not engaging and rushed through the tasks she provided. she also noticed that the quality of the work that her students were completing was decreasing. what should ms. n do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. adopt more varied, purposeful practice tasks. remove purposeful practice from the teaching sequence and add additional modelled and guided practice to ensure her students' engagement. remove purposeful practice from the teaching sequence and add additional modelled and guided practice to ensure her students' engagement. remove purposeful practice from the teaching sequence and add additional modelled and guided practice to ensure her students' engagement. remove purposeful practice from the teaching sequence and add additional modelled and guided practice to ensure her students' engagement. adopt more varied, purposeful practice tasks. please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress page 1 | 4 select a response to continue.

context page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. ms. n knows the value of purposeful practice and wants her students to feel motivated to put effort into the tasks. scenarios: engaging students in purposeful practice

possible solution ms. n decided to focus on motivating her students to improve their effort in completing their work. ms. n introduced extrinsic motivators that rewarded students who increased effort and dealt out consequences for those who didnt. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: engaging students in purposeful practice

this is not the best solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. initially, ms. n noticed some improvement in the quality of the students work. however, after a couple of weeks, the students slipped back into the same patterns. ms. n found herself having to use more extrinsic motivators to encourage students to put effort into their work. she spent an increased amount of time handing out and following through with consequences, and she noticed the climate in the classroom during purposeful practice activities was becoming increasingly tense. after some reflection, ms. n decided to rethink her approach. scenarios: engaging students in purposeful practice

context page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. ms. n knows the importance of student engagement in learning and feels more able to control this when she has greater responsibility for the learning. scenarios: engaging students in purposeful practice

possible solution page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. ms. n decided to remove purposeful practice from the teaching sequence and do more modelled and guided practice with the students. ms. n felt this gave her more control over student engagement as she could quickly respond to students who were not engaged. this also allowed her to readily assess the quality of student work. scenarios: engaging students in purposeful practice

this is not the best solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. from the start, this approach didnt achieve the anticipated outcomes. ms. n had no way of knowing if her students had understood the content, concept or skill she had taught and could apply or transfer it independently. in addition, ms. n noticed her students were becoming increasingly restless and frustrated during the sessions. after some reflection, ms. n decided to rethink her approach. scenarios: engaging students in purposeful practice

context page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. ms. n knows the value of purposeful practice and wants her students to be engaged with and see value in these learning activities. scenarios: engaging students in purposeful practice

possible solution page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. ms. n decided to critically reflect on her practice. she completed an audit of the strategies she had used in her lessons for several months and noticed the same three being implemented. ms. n hypothesised that her students might be getting bored. she decided to add variety to the way purposeful practice was done. ms. n spent time researching and gathering different strategies for engaging students in purposeful practice tasks. she created an online folder with ideas she could quickly draw upon when planning lessons. scenarios: engaging students in purposeful practice

this is a good solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. or, you can return to the course. well done! overall outcome page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. ms. n noticed a significant improvement in her students engagement almost immediately. students were more enthusiastic about completing the varied tasks and put more effort into their work. this increased effort led to students pushing themselves further in their learning, improving academic outcomes. scenarios: engaging students in purposeful practice
